text: [Music]
I grew up in a culture that was very
verbal and argumentative we had a saying
10 Jews 11 opinions Uh I that was part
of the culture there were constant good
natured arguments around the table with
friends and relatives and uh parents but
I think in addition the the 1960s seemed
like a time when everything was up for
grabs you could ask questions like could
we have a society without money uh do we
really need the government uh will cash
be obsolete uh could we Outlaw War uh
questions that seem to hark back to to
the enlightenment when you had thinkers
trying to rationalize the very basis for
society in the 60s it seemed to be okay
to ask those questions uh again I wasn't
part of the 60s movement I was too young
but uh it filtered down to to my circles
because we had older brothers and you
read about it in the papers and saw it
on TV so it was just a time in which
everything seemed up for
grabs people often ask me how my parents
influenced me and I can't give a neutral
answer to that because I'm very much
influenced by a saying by Hans ising
that the biggest influence that parents
have on their children is at the moment
of
conception I think that the
people often uh attribute far too much
to parental uh upbringing there's a fair
amount of data uh from my field that not
widely known that suggests that the
effect of of uh parents in shaping
intellect and personality might even be
uh overrated you see this in in Children
of immigrants even if their parents
never acquired the language and culture
of the adopted country as long as the
kids were immersed in a uh a peer group
uh they end up as F fully competent
citizens something indeed that happened
to my own father the children of
immigrants who are culturally utterly
inept never managed to uh speak the
language in the case of my grandmother
uh we're constantly at Sea and figuring
out the culture and my father grew up
highly successful so if you had asked
the question of him how did your parents
shape you he would have laughed he
shaped himself uh I don't want to deny
credit to my parents who brought me up
in a rich and stim ating uh household
but I think I'd be kind of inventing a
novelistic autobiography which is I
think what most people do when asked how
did your parents uh influence you that
having been said uh it was a a house
with with books with discussion with
arguments with people coming in uh and
uh uh challenging us with interesting
ideas so I wouldn't have traded it for
for anything but the scientist in me
says that warns against my own own
tendency to tell a story and how it
explained uh who I am
today uh I think it's more being
immersed in uh in the the world of ideas
in general one thing that my parents did
that did influence me was by an
encyclopedia which I read almost cover
to cover uh they also subscribe to many
magazines which I would uh uh devour uh
I think most people even though it makes
a good novelistic story to hold up a
role model or a mentor or an
influence uh I I would have to say that
it was um just immersing myself in a
huge sea of ideas that led me to uh my
my my current worldview there are some
things that that were influential at
different parts of my uh adult
professional career I was uh certainly
influenced by uh gome Chomsky my former
colleague at MIT and by uh a number of
the founders of the the so-called
cognitive revolution in the 1950s George
Miller uh Jerome Bruner Roger Brown who
was one of my graduate school uh
mentors uh herb Simon and Alan Newell
Marvin Minsky the people who first came
up with the idea that thinking is a form
of information processing or computation
uh almost allowing us to get a to grasp
on one aspect of the Mind Body problem
How could a physical device result in
intelligence probably the other major
influence was uh from evolutionary
biology from the founders of the uh
Revolution and evolutionary biology that
took place in the 1960s people like
Robert triers George Williams uh John
Maynard Smith William Hamilton who
rethought the nature of evolution and
how complex adaptations could arise from
the process of uh selection among
replicators namely
genes it's natural to to credit who you
are with your parents it seems like an
act of of decency or gratitude and in
fact I often have to apologize to my
parents saying I really do appreciate
everything that you did to me just that
the scientific data lead me to think
that parents don't shape children as
much as most people think and their
attitude is I I should give them credit
for their attitude which is
we wouldn't want you to say anything but
what you believe based on the the best
scientific evidence that uh that you
take seriously so don't try to Fashion
your answer to to flatter us uh I think
that that uh is is a sign of the kind of
people that they are they are I think as
interested in ideas and in providing
good reasons for your ideas uh as I am I
don't know whether I inherited that
whether they fostered it in me but uh
they deserve uh full credit for that
even if perhaps by the standards of
their friends I seem to be denying them
Credit in in talking about theories of
the shaping of
personality I remember my my mentor
Roger Brown once saying um he was one of
the founders of the study of child
language acquisition which is what a lot
of my own research has been uh focused
on and he said you know you'll never
really understand what children are
doing uh this was a a bit of an ironic
comment because of of course that's what
he spent his uh life doing and what I've
dedicated much of my life to doing but
it is a it does offer a little bit of uh
of humility uh and a feeling that if you
don't quite understand everything that's
in your data you shouldn't feel too bad
about it it's extraordinarily complex
we're fortunate to understand uh what we
do understand uh I've gotten advice on
uh writing from uh an early editor of
mine who said uh when you try to present
science to a wide audience don't feel
that you're uh writing for truck drivers
or or uh or chicken Pluckers uh they
probably realistically won't buy your
book and if you try to aim at everyone
you'll end up talking down or
condescending write for your college
roommate someone who you respect as
being a smart as you they went into a
different line of work they're joining
the conversation late they need to be
brought up to speed but assume that your
audience is is as intellectually engaged
and as smart as you are that was a
terrific advice both for teaching and
for uh writing and speaking for a wide
audience
